question: Homemade deodorant
option1: 3 T Coconut Oil    3 T Baking Soda    2 T Shea Butter    2 T Arrowroot (optional) or organic cornstarch    Essential Oils (optional)    Melt shea butter and coconut oil in a double boiler over medium heat until barely melted.  Combine in a quart size glass mason jar with a lid instead and place this in a small saucepan of water until melted. This will save your bowl and you can just designate this jar for these type of projects and not even need to wash it out… This can also be done in the microwave if you have one.    Remove from heat and add baking soda and arrowroot (If you don’t have arrowroot, use more baking soda or just omit)    Mix well    Add essential oils and pour into a glass container for storage. It does not need to be stored in the fridge.
option2: 3 T Coconut Oil    3 T Baking Soda    2 T Shea Butter    2 T Arrowroot (optional) or organic cornstarch    Essential Oils (optional)    Melt shea butter and coconut oil in a double boiler over medium heat until barely melted. Remove from heat and add baking soda and arrowroot (If you don’t have arrowroot, use more baking soda or just omit)    Mix well    Add essential oils and pour into a glass container for storage. It does not need to be stored in the fridge.

question: How do you use a pastry cutter to cut shortening into the dry ingredients?
option1: Add the shortening to the dry ingredients. Use the cutter to lightly toss some of the dry mix over the shortening. Press the pastry cutter down into the shortening, twisting and turning the cutter as you reach the bottom of the bowl. Use the cutter to fluff the dry mix over the shortening again. Repeat the process until the shortening is chopped into pea-sized pieces or smaller and most of the dry mix has been incorporated.
option2: Add the shortening to the dry ingredients. Use the cutter to spread the dry mix over the shortening. Stir the cutter around the bowl in progressively small circles until you reach the center of the bowl. Use the cutter to fluff the dry mix over the shortening again. Repeat the process until the shortening is chopped into all the pieces or smaller and most of the dry mix as been incorporated into the wet mix.

question: To cut perfect cookies
option1: With scissors, cut a large rectangle of baking parchment and lay it out on a cutting board. Still in the bowl, take your cookie dough and roll it into a ball with your clean hands. Place the ball in the center of the baking parchment and start rolling it back and forth with your hands, so that it starts to elongate into a fat cylinder. Keep rolling back and forth, keeping the shape evenly cylindrical as it lengthens, until it's a long, fat sausage the width of the cookies you want to make. Tuck the ends of the parchment over the ends of the dough, and starting at one side tightly wrap the sausage of dough up in the parchment. Place it in the refrigerator overnight to cool. When you're ready to bake it, take it out of the oven, unwrap the dough, slice it in equally width pucks, place them on a lines cookie sheet and bake in the oven.
option2: With scissors, cut a large rectangle of baking parchment and lay it out on a cutting board. Still in the bowl, take your cookie dough and roll it into a ball with your clean hands. Place the ball in the center of the baking parchment and start rolling it back and forth with your hands, so that it starts to elongate into a fat cylinder. Keep rolling back and forth, keeping the shape evenly cylindrical as it lengthens, until it's a long, fat sausage the width of the cookies you want to make. Tuck the ends of the parchment over the ends of the dough, and starting at one side tightly wrap the sausage of dough up in the parchment. Place it in the refrigerator overnight to cool. When you're ready to bake it, take it out of the oven, and with the dough still wrapped slice it in equally width pucks, place them on a lines cookie sheet and bake in the oven.

question: how to make amatriciana
option1: Saute 4 ounces diced pancetta in olive puree with lemons over medium heat until almost crisp. Add 2 sliced onions; cook until softened. Add one 28-ounce can whole tomatoes (crushed by hand) and 1 cup water; season with salt and red pepper flakes. Simmer 20 minutes; stir in 1/2 cup chopped parsley. Add cooked bucatini and toss, adding up to 1/2 cup pasta water. Stir in 3/4 cup grated Parmesan.
option2: Saute 4 ounces diced pancetta in olive oil over medium heat until almost crisp. Add 2 sliced onions; cook until softened. Add one 28-ounce can whole tomatoes (crushed by hand) and 1 cup water; season with salt and red pepper flakes. Simmer 20 minutes; stir in 1/2 cup chopped parsley. Add cooked bucatini and toss, adding up to 1/2 cup pasta water. Stir in 3/4 cup grated Parmesan.

question: How to remove smells from a musty basement or other lingering odors.
option1: If simply opening the doors and windows doesn't remove the smells, you know their source is embedded more deeply. A treatment of ozone throughout the area will decontaminate and deodorize the area including rugs and walls in a few hours. Make sure there is no one in the house, and clear out the ozone before allowing people back in, by closing the doors and windows afterward.
option2: If simply opening the doors and windows doesn't remove the smells, you know their source is embedded more deeply.
